excessive force is being employed
against demonstrators in Venezuela
that's according to a UN team of human
rights investigators which has blamed
security forces for at least 46 deaths
in recent protests the death toll of the
last four months is over a hundred but
that's no deterrent to the opposition
which has promised to block roads later
today in nationwide protests against
president Nicolas Maduro BBC mundo
reporter Daniel Pardo is in Caracas
Daniel what is the latest with the

people who oppose the government of

still want to use protests as a way to

Daniel we'll let them go now to Geneva
we can speak to Raveena
shonda's ani from the UN Human Rights
office thank you for joining us and I
mentioned your report and your concerns
about the use of force and just outline
what your concerns are what we have
documented through remote monitoring of
the human rights situation in Venezuela
is that there is a widespread and
systematic use of excessive force and of
arbitrary detentions now what this means
is that we are not looking at you know
sporadic use of excessive or
disproportionate force by security
officers but consistent systematic
widespread use which we believe is is a
means for them to crush any form of
dissent
we have also documented and in the
course of the detentions many of these
people are subjected to beatings to
ill-treatment which may even ended in
the most severe cases amount to torture
so where does the responsibility for
that lie
well as I said these are widespread and
systematic violations we're documenting
and we are seeing a pattern of
violations in cases like this we say
that the responsibility for these
violations must lie at the highest
levels of government so are you saying
that I mean obviously you're saying that
it is the job of the government to rein
in the security forces but are you
saying that the government is actually
guiding the security forces in this is
that there is effectively blood on the
hands of the government indeed as you
said it is the role of the government to
rein in the security forces to condemn
any kind of disproportionate use of
force to ensure that investigations take
place where there are allegations that
excessive force has been used to
cooperate with the investigations that
were launched by the Attorney General's
Office unfortunately what we have seen
is more crushing of dissent and in fact
we have recently seen the sacking of the
Attorney General herself now we are very
concerned about the status of these
investigations that were launched by her
we urge the government to continue with
these investigations to ensure that
there are meaningful credible
independent investigations of every
single account where excessive force was
alleged to have been committed by
security forces but when you talk about
your your concerns of what the security
forces are doing are they doing it on
the direct orders of the government is
there blood on the hands of the
government well it is impossible for us
to know whether they have been direct
orders but as I said what we are seeing
is patterns of violations widespread and
systematic violations which cannot be
conducted without the knowledge of the
government and as I said as well the
government has failed to condemn these
violations
which is their duty they have failed to
investigate these violations which once
again is their duty we are seeing
arbitrary detention at very high scale
reports suggest that more than 5000
people have been arbitrarily detained
from 1,000 remain in detention and while
in detention we have documented cases of
torture and ill-treatment people being
hung by their wrists this form of
systematic crushing of dissent cannot be
carried out without the knowledge of the
government what what can what should the
Internet
no community do the reason why we
conducted this remote monitoring first
of all we the High Commissioner for
Human Rights had requested access to
Venezuela to be able to you know for us
to be able to go to the ground and
document the human rights situation
there we fail to get this access we then
decided to deploy a remote monitoring
team to conduct our own investigations
from Panama now the point of these
investigations is to draw the attention
of the international community to what
is happening in Venezuela to give an
objective and independent account of
what is happening in the face of a lot
of propaganda that's coming out from the
country the international community
needs to react and we will be publishing
a final report with the full findings
with a legal analysis and with
recommendations for steps for the way
forward at the end of August
thank you very much Raveena Shan Dasani
from the UN Human Rights office
